docs.lead_paragraph: In a barely audible, childlike monotone that gave little hint of remorse, the 20-year-old woman who delivered her child during her high school prom last year and then placed his body in a trash can pleaded guilty today to aggravated manslaughter in the child's death. The woman, Melissa Drexler of Forked River, N.J., entered her plea in Superior Court in Monmouth County as part of a plea agreement that had been in place for more than a month. Her original court date of July 9 had been postponed by Judge John A. Ricciardi without explanation.

headline.main: Guilty Plea By Mother, 20, In Prom Death

docs.abstract: Melissa Drexler, 20-year-old Forked River, NJ, woman who delivered her child during her high school prom last year and then placed his body in trash can, pleads guilty to aggravated manslaughter in child's death; Superior Court Judge John A Ricciardi accepts plea and sets sentencing for Oct 29 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This village is really just a muddy patch of ground in the tall trees near where the Nile flows out of Lake Victoria. The men work on coffee plantations. The women bear children, fetch water from the well about a mile away and cultivate cassava, potatoes and bananas. There is no running water, no electricity, no phone. When the long rains come each year they wash out the dirt road for weeks at a time. This is -- and has always been -- a place where people who reach the age of 50 are old, and those who have seen a doctor or swallowed a pill are rare.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW often has your clock radio awakened you with the distressing news that something you eat, drink, breathe or do has just been shown in a new study to be a serious health hazard? And how often did it turn out to be a false alarm, unsupported by subsequent research? The American Council on Science and Health, based in New York, recently updated and expanded its popular report, ''Facts Versus Fears,'' reviewing what it considers the greatest unfounded health scares of the last five decades. Although controversy continues to rage about potential risks associated with some of these ''scares,'' including Agent Orange and hormones in beef, most -- including those that resulted in serious economic damage and changes in public policy -- have been soundly discounted by subsequent studies.

headline.main: Personal Health; Health Scares That Weren't So Scary

docs.lead_paragraph: Cynthia Salomon was 7 months' pregnant when her husband, Jose Lazo, was diagnosed with testicular cancer. It was Jan. 8, their daughter's second birthday. They had three jobs between them -- he cooked in two restaurants, she answered the telephone in a bank. But by Feb. 3, after his first operation, she was just another applicant for relief and Medicaid at the East End Income Support Center. Ms. Salomon waited for hours at the Manhattan welfare center, only to be sent home to call for an appointment. She called 15 times a day to get through. She submitted hospital records, rent receipts, birth certificates and bank statements, dealing with caseworkers trained to push people to work.

headline.main: Illness, a New Baby, and Then a Struggle for Assistance

docs.abstract: Article on difficulty that Cynthia Salomon and Jose Lazo of East Harlem had in getting Medicaid assistance after he was diagnosed with testicular cancer and she had baby (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bobbie Ann Mason (Op-Ed, Aug. 13) chides the school administrators in Lexington, Ky., for denying membership in the National Honor Society to two teen-age mothers. She doesn't detail the academic and community achievements of the two young women, so it is difficult to determine why they were selected as candidates.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just before Shakespeare's ''Cymbeline'' opened in June at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the directors Adrian Noble and Andrei Serban talked in these pages about staging this rarely seen adventure-comedy-romance in nearly back-to-back versions. Mr. Noble's, by the Royal Shakespeare Company, was his first attempt at directing the play. So, too, with Mr. Serban, whose ''Cymbeline'' opens tonight at the Delacorte Theater, part of the New York Shakespeare Festival's 43d season in Central Park.

headline.main: A New 'Cymbeline' of Moon, Grass and Trees

docs.abstract: Andrea Stevens previews Andrei Serban production of Shakespeare's Cymbeline, set to open at Delacorte Theater as part of New York Shakespeare Festival's new season; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Abortion Debated in Chile, Where It's Always a Crime'' (news article, Aug. 9): Jailing abortion providers will not stop women from seeking abortions or from risking their lives to do so. It will drive up costs and force even more women to undergo unsafe procedures. Furthermore, it will do nothing to reduce the underlying cause of abortion: lack of access to contraceptives and to comprehensive sexual and reproductive counseling and services.
docs.abstract: International Women's Health Coalition spokeswoman Elizabeth Leitman letter responds to Aug 9 article; contends that jailing abortion providers will not stop Chilean women from seeking abortions or from risking their lives to do so
